Expectation1: Complete assigned tasks by the agreed deadlines
Situation1: The task has generous buffer time and others can proceed without it for a while.
Expectation2: Enforcing the law and maintaining public order
Situation2: An armed robbery is in progress, posing immediate threat to lives and property
Story: I sat at my desk, the hum of the office around me, my mind focused on the report I needed to finish for my team. The deadline wasn’t tight—there was plenty of buffer, and my colleagues could keep moving without my part for a bit. Still, I knew they expected me to pull my weight, to be reliable and not let things pile up. Just as I was about to dive in, my police radio crackled to life. An armed robbery, just blocks away. The dispatcher’s voice was urgent—shots fired, people in danger. My heart pounded. As a police officer, I was sworn to protect, to respond without hesitation when lives were at stake. But as a colleague, I was supposed to be present, dependable, not the one always running out and leaving others to pick up the slack. I stared at my half-finished report, then at my badge. The weight of both roles pressed down on me, each demanding something different, each impossible to ignore.
